Description: The Leaflet Storymaps code template is designed to guide readers along a point-by-point tour, with a scrolling narrative to display text, images, audio, video, and scanned map backgrounds. Readers can follow the scrolling narrative or click on any marker to go directly to a specific chapter. You can create your own version by entering your map data into a linked Google Sheet (or CSV file) and uploading it into a free GitHub repository to host online. Learn more in our book, Hands-On Data Visualization.

Since storymaps work best with a narrative that ties together your locations, we'll demonstrate the features of this tool with a very brief story about the US National Mall in Washington, DC. Let's zoom out for a bird's-eye view of our story.

View of the National Mall from the top of the Washington Monument, looking east toward the US Capitol, which was constructed in 1829.

Right-click on the tiny "View data" link at the bottom of the map to open the contents of the linked Google Sheet in a new tab. Each row is a chapter, which contains the text of the story, links to media, and data about each point on the map. The Google Sheet also includes an "Options" tab with global settings for the overall map appearance.

Media Credit: Source: US National Park Service, public domain
Description:
You can upload JPG or PNG images into the media subfolder of your GitHub repository and enter their file pathname into the linked Google Sheet. The template automatically resizes images to fit the scrolling narrative, but we recommend reducing images to 600 x 400 pixels or less before uploading to make sure your storymap scrolls smoothly. Note that media file pathnames are case-sensitive, and we recommend using all lowercase characters, including the suffix ending.

The Washington Monument, constructed in 1884, stands at the center of what people informally refer to as the Mall, halfway between the US Capitol and the Lincoln Memorial.

Media Credit: Source: Anthony Citrano/Flickr, Creative Commons BY-NC-ND
Description:
Also, you can link directly to photos in external web servers, such as Flickr and Wikimedia. To add a Flickr photo, click its Share button, choose a small-to-medium size, copy its embed code, and paste only the portion with the web address that begins with "https://live.staticflickr.com/...." and ends in JPG or PNG. To add a Wikimedia image, select a small-to-medium size and copy its direct link, which ends in JPG or PNG. Always credit your image sources.

The Lincoln Memorial was constructed at the western edge of the Mall in 1922.

Chapter: March on Washington at Lincoln Memorial, 1963
Media Credit: Source: Agence France Presse/Getty Images, published by National Public Radio (2010)
Description:
You can display multiple images for one location by creating a series of rows in the Google Sheet. List the Chapter and Location information only in the first row of the series, and leave those fields blank for the other rows. Insert text and image links in the other columns. Also, for each row you have three options for the Marker column: Numbered, Plain, or Hidden (which works best for multiple chapters on one location, to avoid stacking markers on top of one another).

The Lincoln Memorial has been the setting for many civil rights protests, such as Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s speech during the 1963 March on Washington.

Chapter: "I Have A Dream" Speech by Dr. King, 1963
Media Credit: Source: "Talk of the Nation," National Public Radio (2010)
Description:
In addition to images, you can also upload or link to audio files, which must be in one of these formats: mp3 (recommended), ogg, or wav. The template will automatically recognize audio files and allow readers to play them.

Listen to this short audio excerpt from Dr. King's 1963 speech at the Lincoln Memorial.

Media Credit: Source: "The Healing Wall" (2015), a film by Christopher Kosinski
Description:
You can also embed a link from a streaming video service such as YouTube. Click on the YouTube video Share button, select Embed, and copy and paste only the web link, which will look similar to this:
https://www.youtube.com/embed/Q-082gadmDw

Optionally, you can add user controls and a start time to the link and make it look like this:
https://www.youtube.com/embed/Q-082gadmDw?controls=0&start=17

The Vietnam Veterans Memorial, designed by architect Maya Lin, was located near the Lincoln Memorial in 1982. Watch a portion of this video to learn more.

In addition, you can display georeferenced historical maps on top of your storymap to contrast with present-day maps. See the Overlay column in the linked Google Sheet for this chapter, and learn more in Chapter 14: Transform Your Map Data of our book.

This facsimile of Pierre (Peter) Charles L'Enfant's 1791 map, downloaded from an 1887 publication at the Library of Congress, illustrates his grand design for the permanent seat of government, which he presented to President George Washington in the early days of the new republic.

Also, you can add a GeoJSON layer of a route, boundary, or choropleth map on top of the storymap. See the GeoJSON column in the linked Google Sheet.

Route of the 1851 Washington Canal through the Mall.

The code template assigns each chapter a unique web address that ends with a numerical hashtag (such as ...#12). This corresponds to the spreadsheet row number, not the marker number column, which may be duplicated or hidden. This means you can send people links to specific chapters, or refer back to another chapter in this storymap, such as this internal link to chapter 3.
To learn more about the Leaflet Storymaps with Google Sheets template, see our book: Hands-On Data Visualization.
